physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry Monroe” are written in pencil at the top.

encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p: I am not frightfully flush this year. I am afraid nobody is; and I am afraid I can only agree to give you $50. in cash on the first of August, instead of $100. as I gave you last year. But I am putting in a big, full-page advertisement of “Some Imagist Poets” in your July issue. I have just given the order to Houghton Mifflin. And my French lectures are coming out in the Autumn and will, of course, be advertised for two or three months in your paper. So I can make up the $100. in that way; in fact, it will make more. If I find on the first of August that I have enough to give you more, I certainly will. Perhaps when the account of my various books comes in, I shall have a little more than I think, in which case I shall certainly complete my donation in cash to the extent of my ability.

I hope you and Alice Henderson are reviewing “Some Imagist Poets” pretty soon. We are
getting fine black eyes all over the place. Did you see Conrad Aiken’s in the last “New Republic?”

I am going to suggest to “The New Republic” writing up your magazine for some early Autumn number, and giving a list of your most unusual accomplishment in it. If they won’t take it, and I should not wonder if they would not, I shall try to do it for the “Transcript” here. I think October or November would be a good time, when people are back in town and considering
subscriptions and things for the winter. As I wrote you, I have been so impressed with what you have done since your starting and I think it ought to have some great heralding.
